subject: bmcweb: Remove hardcoded HTTP verbs and headers
commitMessage:
bmcweb: Remove hardcoded HTTP verbs and headers

Modifies HttpClient so that the HTTP verb and headers can be set
for each individual message sent.  Right now those fields are set
when a connection is first created and then reused by each
message sent using that connection.

Tested:
Launched two Event Listener servers that created 6 and 2
subscriptions.  Sending a test event resulted in the servers
receiving 6 requests and 2 requests, respectively.

Change-Id: I8d7e2d54385bc2c403498293820adb584bff8b57
Signed-off-by: Carson Labrado <clabrado@google.com>
Signed-off-by: Ed Tanous <edtanous@google.com>

Change has been successfully merged

4 of these fields (data, uri, verb, and httpHeader) are duplicated with the http::Request class,.  Should we just hold an http::Request as a member here?

It has better validation of things like URIs than this class does, which I suspect could be important.  It looks like in the later code we just contruct an http::Request from this data anyway.

Yeah that should be fine. I now just construct the http:Request in ConnectionPool.sendData().  If a connection is available then that request is moved to the connection, otherwise it gets moved to the queue of pending requests.
Looks like you went with the boost::messages::request version of that, which is fine, and solves the problem I pointed out.
Both of these are copies of potentially large objects.  I suspect you want to std::move these.
I've made the change
One super minor thing on copying payloads, then this looks good to go.
As written, this is making a complete copy of the request, which, given its size, we ideally shouldn't.  Can we accept this by &&, then use std::move on line 82?
Sure thing, I've made the change
Made one super innocent style change (constructing a request in place instead of with operator=) on your last commit.
